a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: This is a signed draft of "Funeral Interpolations," a poem published first as "Over and Through the Burial Chant" in the New York Herald on August 12, 1888, on the occasion of General Philip Henry Sheridan's death (on August 5), and later as "Interpolation Sounds" in Good-Bye My Fancy (1891).

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: Funeral Interpolations
bibl.orgName: Walt Whitman Literary Manuscripts in The Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

The prose drafted on the back of these and several other related manuscript leaves includes ideas and phrases that resemble those used in "Unnamed Lands," a poem published first in the 1860 edition of Leaves of Grass.

note.del:
Put this in the day of Sheridan's
burial ceremonies — personal

lg.head: 533[Funeral Sounds not inInterpolations
lg.l: Over and through the burial chant,

Organ and solemn service, sermon, bending
priests

To one come ‸interpolation⹀stealing⹀sounds not in the show —
plainly to me all throughalthroughout ‸crowding up the aisle
and ‸from the window, sounding,

Of sudden battle's hurry and harsh noises —
war's, war's grim game to sight and
ear in earnest,

The rifle⹀crack — the cannon thud —
rushing –forth of men from their tents,

The clank of cavalry — the strange celerity
of forming ranks — the slender bugle note.

The sound of horses's hoofshooves departing — saddles
arms, accoutrements.
